item.title: Delhi Police issues traffic advisory ahead of PM Narendra Modi's events today | Check restrictions - Hindustan Times
item.description:

  • PM Modi will inaugurate and lay foundation stones for seven projects.
  • He will visit newly constructed flats under the In-Situ Slum Rehabilitation Project.
  • Traffic restrictions will be enforced on specific routes to manage VVIP traffic.

  2. GTK Road: Azadpur Chowk to Gurudwara Nanak Pio.
  3. Bhamashah Marg: Model Town-1 to Nanak Pio.
  4. Lala Achhintam Marg & Brahma Kumari Marg: Gujranwala & Derawal areas.
  5. Nahar Singh Marg: Prembari Chowk to Inderlok Metro Station (both sides).
  6. Gulab Singh Marg: Satyawati College to Prerna Chowk.
  7. Swami Narayan Marg: Delhi Jal board Red Light to Laxmi Bai College.
  8. Mahatma Gandhi Marg: Britannia Chowk to Azadpur.

Date and Time of Restrictions

Traffic restrictions will be in effect from 9am to 4pm on January 3. Residents are advised to plan their journeys accordingly.

“Motorists are encouraged to stay updated on traffic conditions through the Delhi Traffic Police's official channels.”

This advisory emphasizes the importance of following traffic rules during the VVIP movements to ensure smooth flow and public convenience.

item.title: Foreign hiker detained at Delhi airport for carrying banned GPS device - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Foreign hiker detained at Delhi airport for carrying banned GPS device

Date: Jan 03, 2025

Source: HT News Desk

A Scottish hiker, Heather, claimed that she was detained at Delhi airport for allegedly carrying a banned Garmin Inreach GPS device. She reported that security personnel informed her of the ban upon her passing through security.

  • Heather was detained on January 3, 2025, at Delhi airport for carrying a Garmin Inreach device.
  • She was informed that the device is banned in India and was subsequently handed over to police.
  • Heather recorded her experience in a video posted on Instagram.
  • Despite contacting her embassy, they could not intervene as she was under police custody.
  • After questioning, she was allowed to leave but must return for a court appearance.
  • A similar incident occurred with a Czech national in Goa for possessing a different banned GPS device.
“At 9pm, I was finally released from the police station, but I am required to return to attend court,” Heather stated.

This incident highlights ongoing issues regarding the carrying of specific technological devices into India and the need for awareness among travelers about local regulations.

item.description:
On road to Maha Kumbh, the 84 ‘pillars of faith’: ‘It’s a symbolic way to attain moksha’

Publication Date: Not specified Source: The Indian Express

With 10 days left for the Maha Kumbh, the Uttar Pradesh government is installing 84 red sandstone pillars known as “Aastha Ke Sthambh (pillars of faith)” along the road to the airport in Prayagraj.

  • The installation will cost Rs 17 crore, each pillar costing around Rs 20 lakh.
  • Each pillar features 108 names of Lord Shiva and is topped with a kalash (pitcher).
  • The 84 pillars symbolize a journey through 84 lakh yonis, reflecting the teachings of Sanatan Dharma philosophy.
  • An estimated 40 to 45 crore devotees are expected to visit during the Maha Kumbh from January 13 to February 26.
“Life is a huge journey going through the infinite cycles of birth and death, the soul changes its form 84 lakh times in an attempt to find itself.” - Acharya Mithlesh Nandani Sharan

This initiative aims to enhance the experience of devotees by connecting them with the philosophical significance of the Maha Kumbh.

item.title: CISF sees 40% decline in deaths among its personnel - The Hindu
item.description:
CISF Achieves 40% Decrease in Personnel Suicide Rates

Published: January 02, 2025 11:18 pm IST | Source: The Hindu

The Central Industrial Security Force (CISF) has reported a significant 40% decline in deaths by suicide among its personnel, attributed to proactive measures implemented within the force. The national suicide rate has simultaneously risen in India.

  • The CISF suicide rate decreased from 12.4 per lakh in 2022 to 9.87 per lakh in 2024.
  • Proactive measures included personalized engagements and an online grievance portal for timely support.
  • Approximately 4,200 personnel received mental health support through 24x7 counselling services.
  • A comprehensive mental health study conducted with AIIMS, New Delhi, informed actionable steps.
  • A new HR policy aims to improve work-life balance, focusing on personal needs and mental health.
“It is for the first time in the last five years that CISF suicide rate has fallen below the national rate,” sources mentioned.

These initiatives showcase an effective response to the increasing mental health challenges faced by security personnel in India.

item.title: Karnataka: Woman kills husband, smashes his face with stone, chops body - Hindustan Times
item.description:
Woman Arrested for Murdering Husband, Disposing Body in Karnataka

Date: Jan 02, 2025
Source: Hindustan Times

A woman in Karnataka's Belagavi was arrested for allegedly murdering her husband and chopping his body, police said on Thursday.

  • The woman allegedly strangled her 40-year-old husband, identified as Srimantha Itnali, and then smashed his face with a stone.
  • She cut his body into two pieces to dispose of it away from her house.
  • The incident took place on December 8, and the body was found on December 10 in Umarani village in Chikkodi taluk of Belagavi.
  • The police initially did not suspect the woman, but later brought her in for questioning, and she confessed to the crime.
  • The husband was reportedly a drunkard who abused his wife for money and wanted her to sell a piece of land to buy him a new motorbike.
"She first strangled him and when he was unconscious, used a boulder lying nearby to smash his face. She then disposed of the boulder in a well."

The woman has been taken into custody.

item.title: Government report reveals stark infrastructure gap in Indian schools - The Hindu
item.description:
Government Report Highlights Infrastructure Gaps in Indian Schools

Date: January 02, 2025
Source: The Hindu

The latest report by the Unified District Information System for Education (UDISE+) reveals alarming gaps in infrastructure across Indian schools, with many lacking essential facilities like electricity, functional toilets, and access to computers.

  • Out of 14.71 lakh schools in India, 1.52 lakh have no functional electricity.
  • Only 67,000 schools operate without functional toilets, mainly affecting government schools.
  • Only 33.2% of government schools have disabled-friendly toilets, with fewer being functional.
  • 50% of all schools lack access to computers for educational purposes.
  • Only 10.5% of schools have implemented solar panel facilities.
  • Only 17.5% of schools have co-curricular activity rooms or arts and crafts facilities.
  • In government secondary schools, 50.2% have science laboratory facilities.
"The condition is much worse when it comes to providing disabled-friendly facilities, with only 33.2% of schools having disabled-friendly toilets."

This report underscores a significant need for improvement in the infrastructure of schools in India, especially for the government-run institutions.

item.title: Article 370 caused spread of terrorism in Kashmir: Amit Shah - The Hindu
item.description:
Amit Shah: Article 370 Fueled Terrorism in Kashmir

Published on: January 02, 2025 | Source: The Hindu

Union Home Minister Amit Shah claims that Article 370 has played a critical role in fostering terrorism in Kashmir, attributing it to the notion of temporary relations between Kashmir and India.

  • Article 370 fostered separatism among Kashmiri youth, leading to terrorism.
  • Other Muslim-majority regions in India did not experience similar terrorism despite sharing borders with Pakistan.
  • Mr. Shah stated that the misconception of Kashmir's relationship with India promoted extremism.
  • The revocation of Article 370 on August 5, 2019, must be understood in the larger historical context.

“Why did terrorism not spread in other Muslim areas of the country? ... It is unfortunate that 40,000 people lost their lives,” Mr. Shah said.

The Home Minister further emphasized the importance of re-evaluating Kashmir's history and offered perspectives that could reshape national narratives.
